dt: {bc}to clean the coat of (an animal, such as a horse) with a {a_link|currycomb}
{bc}to treat (tanned leather) especially by incorporating oil or grease

et: Middle English {it}curreyen, correyen, cunrayen{/it} "to clean and comb (a horse), treat (tanned leather)," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}conreier, cunreier, curreier{/it} (continental Old French {it}conreer{/it}) "to prepare, dress, equip, tidy up, clean and rub down (an animal), cure (herring)," going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*conrēdāre,{/it} probably borrowed from Gothic {it}garedan{/it} "to make provision for" (with {it}con-{/it} {et_link|con-|com-} replacing {it}ga-{/it}), from {it}ga-,{/it} perfective and collective prefix + {it}-redan,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*rēđan-{/it} "to make provision for, decide" {ma}{mat|read:1|}{/ma}

As with the related verb {it}arraier, aroier{/it} (see {et_link|array:1|array:1}), the Anglo-French forms {it}conreier,{/it} etc., show generalization of the tonic stem of the Old French verb. English has further modified the French word by shifting stress onto the initial syllable. In contrast with {et_link|array:1|array:1}, the more general meaning of {it}conreier{/it} ("provide, equip") never entered English. — The presumption is that {it}*conrēdāre{/it} was an early adaptation into spoken Latin of a word used by Goths recruited into or fighting alongside of the Roman army. The etymon is generally attested in Romance languages outside of Romanian: Old Occitan {it}conrezar{/it} "to equip," {it}conrear{/it} "to provide what is needed," Catalan & Spanish {it}conrear{/it} "to cultivate (land)" (the Spanish word perhaps borrowed from Catalan), Italian {it}corredare{/it} "to equip, furnish" (with an apparent reflex of open rather than close {it}e{/it}).
shortdef: to clean the coat of (an animal, such as a horse) with a currycomb
to treat (tanned leather) especially by incorporating oil or grease

dt: {bc}to flavor or cook with curry powder or a curry sauce

shortdef: to flavor or cook with curry powder or a curry sauce

dt: {bc}to seek to gain favor by flattery or attention

dt.t: … eager to {wi}curry favor{/wi} with superiors by reporting any trivial transgression.

aq.auth: Robert Wallace and H. Keith Meltony

dt.t: Instead of rolling back environmental regulations to {wi}curry favor{/wi} with corporate interests, California has passed the toughest green laws in the nation …

et: The idiom {it}curry favor{/it} is an alteration by folk etymology of {it}curry favell,{/it} Middle English {it}core favele, currey favel{/it} "to use insincere flattery to gain personal advantage," literally, "to curry the fallow-colored horse," a translation of Middle French {it}estriller/torchier Fauvel{/it} "to use trickery, deceive," literally, "to curry/clean Fauvel" ("the fallow one," as a name for a horse). Old & Middle French {it}falve, fauve{/it} "brownish-yellow, light brown (of an animal's coat)" and its derivatives have the additional meaning "false, hypocritical," probably in part due to the similarity in sound to {it}faux{/it} "false"; hence {it}la fauve asnele{/it} (ca. 1170) "hypocrisy, falsehood" (literally, "the fallow ass"), {it}fauvoier{/it} (13th century) "to deceive," Old Occitan {it}falveta{/it} "art of beguiling." {it}Fauvel{/it} and {it}Fauvain{/it} as horse's names are the focus of various idioms, as {it}estriller Fauvel{/it} "to curry Fauvel," that denote duplicitous behavior. In the satirical French poem, {it}Roman de Fauvel,{/it} composed ca. 1310-16, a horse or donkey named Fauvel becomes king by the grace of {it}Fortuna{/it} ("Lady Fortune") and, having taken possession of the palace stable, is curried and cleaned by the hypocritical nobility and clergy of the realm.
shortdef: to seek to gain favor by flattery or attention
